Will definitely make this place my watering hole. Great service, great beer (I personally liked the Wheat beer), and great food. I had the roasted half bird (chicken two ways) and the reservoir salad... Both dishes were well balanced and delicious. 
This place has the ambiance I was looking for, cannot wait to come back.
author: Valerie K.

description: #NotMyNeighborhoodWateringHole. I was not impressed with the beer. Both beers I ordered tasted like it came from the bottom of the keg. The service was subpar; both the bartender and host looked miserable. I will give them one star for the interior but it feels like they are trying to appeal to one demographic. Just because you know how to brew beer doesn't mean you should open up a brewery.
author: Richard B.

description:
This place was very cool. 

We had a reservation and ate on the 2nd floor,  which I much prefer.   It also has its own bathrooms up there which is a huge plus. 

We had a table of 8 or so people and we basically ordered 3/4 of the entire menu,  with duplicates.   It was kinda crazy and we absolutely threw down on food!   The plates just kept rolling in.   They did end up forgetting to make a couple dishes but our server was quite apologetic and put the really late arriving dish on the house and comped us a pitcher of beer.  I really appreciate that kind of service.  We all know that any mac and cheese dish is heavy but their pasta bowl is quite heavy as well.  Just a warning. 

This place was cool.
author: Gilbert C.

description:
Strong on the hoppiness/ibu - stout and vanilla brown too hoppy for me
Pork tacos were good, roasted brussel sprouts a little too toasty but interesting lime and chili flavor
author: Mam C.

description: Yuppie brewery with tasteful beers. I like the decor of the place with its high ceilings and wooden patterns. The wait staff were very nice in answering questions about the wait time and ordering drinks at the bar. The flight of six beers consisted of light and dark beers. Great way to catch up with some friends and try new beer. Friday night waits tend to be around 40 minutes for food, so I recommend staying by the bar area and grabbing an available seat there.
author: Joanne K.

description:
I was really hoping to like this place, but sadly I didn't end up enjoying either the food or the beer.

I got the burger which was supposed to come have bacon and guac on it or something but ended up coming with just tomato, onion, and, heaven forbid, iceberg lettuce. You know when you order a burger and it doesn't come already assembled? They put the toppings on the side so you can put on whichever veggies you like. It came like that, which usually isn't a good sign. I want my sandwiches to be crafted. This ain't Subway. I imagine that bacon/guac/russian dressing burger would've been like that, but that's not what I got.

But it gets worse. They asked how I wanted it cooked. I requested medium rare, which usually yields medium and I'm okay with that. What do I get? Well done. Why does this happen so much in San Francisco? Maybe they noticed I was some Yelp food critic like on South Park and wanted to get my hopes up about a 145º burger for the lolz.

The fries were good, though.

Now for the beer. I got the sampler which came with the Sour Wheat, Rye Amber, English IPA, Alt Bier, Dry Irish Stout, and Russian Imperial Stout. Out of these, I think only the Dry Stout or the Imperial Stout are worth getting. I was mostly disappointed with the English IPA because it was way too cloudy plus I think the style was a bit off; I feel like the hops they used were unorthodox for a traditional English IPA.

If the food here gets better I could see myself coming back, but from reading the other reviews it doesn't seem like much has changed. Oh well.
author: Andrew D.

description: Well not so great The noise level is just unbearable.  The server was terribly inexperienced.  Food was good.
author: Vanessa B.

description: Came here on a Friday night around 7pm with a 30 minute wait.  Couldn't get a drink at the bar because it was that crowded.  Ambiance is hip. Ordered cocktails when we finally sat at our table but it came after our appetizers; something about being backed up.  Peppers and peach/spinach salad were good.  My partner and I always share our dishes. I had the fish & chips w/garlic fries and he had the portobello mushrooms w/regular fries; both were just ok. Fish looked burnt but maybe it was dark beer used for the beer batter. It didn't taste burnt but it was just ok.  Both fries tasted like it was sitting - soggy and a bit hard. The portobello burger was ok too.  I'm not sure I'll come back but to support a local restaurant in the Sunset.
author: Becca D.

description: Happy to find a place that has decent food and it was great for kids as well.   The food was not too bad for a Brewery, but loved the space.  Will definitely consider this for group parties on their second floor.
author: Edgar C.

description:
The best thing about this place is the facility itself. A nice and spacious interior that has style. Comfortable, roomy, and not crowded. It's a great setting.

The beer, service, and food are good, but nothing stands out as great.
author: Wolf H.

description: This place seems to be always busy, especially if there's a game going on. It also seems to be understaffed with not necessarily the friendliest of staff. Maybe because there's not enough staff, they feel overworked and not the happiest. Other than that, it's pretty much the only brewery in the outer sunset, so unless another one comes along, this place is convenient for the area. But a sports bar will always be a sports bar.
author: Linda H.

description: I'm sorry to say that this restaurant appears to have seriously declined in quality.  I've returned a handful of times since my last review, and on every visit, they were "out" of one or more of the already limited selection of brews.  And what beers are available are mediocre at best.  The once-superb burger, too, has completely lost its flavor and appeal.  I don't know that I will ever go back to what was once my favorite local restaurant.
author: Paula B.

description:
We discovered SRBC last year when we moved to SF. We loved it - has a cool feel (wood/metal/very industrial almost farm house like), good food & plentiful beer options. The area upstairs is great for large parties. We used to make this a weekly stop. But recently things have changed and I won't be going back.

Word is, there is a new brewmaster.My husband loves beer - they had a big selection until recently but now they only have 4 selections. I'm gluten sensitive so I can't drink beer but I loved their cider. They no longer have cider. 

There is also a new chef. Some of my family's favorite items are no longer offered - such as the warm pretzels. Thankfully they kept the fried chicken - my family LOVES the fried chicken! Also, their cole slaw is delicious as is their mashed potatoes (hold the gravy, gluten free-ers!)

Unfortunately, the gluten free options I enjoyed such as the Risotto and the Sauteed Greens (with bacon, shallots & mushrooms) are no more. The options for me now are salad, a bunless burger (which is very greasy and is always served without any condiments), a roasted half-chicken. Not too much variety. 

The waitstaff is drastically under-educated about the needs of gluten sensitive customers. It would do the ownership some good to notate items on the menu that are gluten free or can be made gluten free, to spare the waitstaff the million questions & spare the customer a "let's hope for the best!" The waitstaff is quick to say if something has gluten but they don't always connect the dots with the shared fryers and don't offer ways items could be served gluten free.  I was reassured a few times that their fries and their new brussell sprouts are gluten free, only they aren't - they are fried in the same oil as their flour foods. I knew I had felt off after consuming these, just wasn't sure if it was due to other reasons. 

Water is served in small (like 4oz) glasses, which can be annoying if you aren't drinking beer - you have to wait for someone to notice and come by to fill it.

I won't be returning to SRBC as it seems the recent changes with menu & beer selection make the visit more cumbersome than enjoyable.
author: j m.

description:
Great beer for a great price! Also the food is pretty good too, the sides are great for sharing. I had the fried chicken main plate and it was delicious!

The service is awesome! The bartender was great and helped me pick out the perfect beer. Our waitress Maddie was awesome, too! 

My only complaint was that it was hot upstairs where we ate, but it was an unusual weather day of 89 degrees outside. I bet any other day it would have felt just fine up there.
author: Melody C.

description: The Sunset needed a place like this. If the line out the door is any indication, this is a welcome addition to the neighborhood. We only came for drinks...we had a such a good time, we were late for dinner at Mom's! The hubby liked the Amber, I loved the Wheat and the Stout was pretty good too! Untapped already shows good reviews! Menu looks great. Great neighborhood feel and nice urban decor. I hope that this place does well. Can't wait to try the flatbread, rabbit and oysters next time!
author: Bernadette W.

description: I had a party of about 15 ppl for my boyfriends surprise 25th birthday. Let me say, the staff there...AMAZING! I loved seeing them come around and check in on us. They never rushed us for anything. This place is so urban but very chill. Love it. I will def. be coming back again!
author: Jenn P.

description: Don't get me wrong, I'm really happy to have a brewery this close to my house. The Sunset Brewery has a nice clean atmosphere and decor, pretty decent food, tvs for sports (although always without sound), and plenty of tables. However the beer is far from award winning compared to other sf breweries. The only decent one I've had is the sourdough sour beer. The rest haven't really been that good at all. The prices are standardly high for SF, which is residents have unfortunately become accustomed to. I believe the owners of this place are good sunset neighborhood loving people who are fulfilling a dream. But the beer here is not a reason to visit.
author: Jackson W.

description:
I was excited to try this new spot on a lesser traveled side of town. It's always nice to see the Sunset get some shiny new spots to hang out. We stopped in on a Sunday afternoon, and sat right down. It's probably a good idea to try the place on an off time, or to make a reservation. I hear they're pretty busy still. 

The beer flight was refreshing, and the pours were decent. The sour wheat and maibock were my personal favorites. They now have 6 beers on tap. 

The wife's Bloody Mary was stiff, and super flavorful. 

On to the food:

Fried Chicken Sando - the chicken was perfectly fried and juicy, and we added a fried egg for a brunchy punch. 

Portabello Mushroom Sando - there were a few very tiny portobello mushrooms inside, and it left me wishing they had used a large portobello mushroom instead. There was too much bread in relation to the filling. 

Also, on the menu they list that they serve the sandwiches with salad, and it's $2 extra to add fries, which I did. But when the sandwich arrived, I received fries -- but no salad. They should change the wording on the menu to say "Substitute Fries" instead of "Add Fries" so there isn't any confusion. 

Green Posole - we originally ordered the green Posole, but the kitchen changed it to Red Posole. The broth was savory, and the chickpeas and hominy were tender. Solid dish. 

Cajun Gulf Prawns sautéed in Beer - the prawns were awesome, and left with the heads on so we could suck the juice out. Amazing! The sauce was a bit on the bitter side from the beer, but didn't kill the dish. It was a bit pricy though, at $18 for only 5 prawns. 

Whisky Caramel Pot De Creme with Candied Peanuts - OMG!!!!! This was so amazingly delicious, I could eat a whole trough of this stuff. 


The service was attentive, and our server was nice and informative. 

Overall a solid experience, albeit with a few hiccups. I'm sure things will smooth out, and I plan to return to try some more dishes. This place definitely has the potential to be a local favorite.
author: Isaias G.

description:
The few times I've been, and few other times I've tried to go the special seems to be attitude! Whether it be the bartender who ignores you or the host/hostess who gives (unjustified) attitude it runs thick here!  
Once you finally get a drink and get past the keeper of the wait list the food has been good and the service staff great.
author: Us And J.

description: Love this place! Great neighborhood ,atmosphere, the food is yummy, and brunch is great, too! We come here often when we want to go somewhere that offers American fare in the beloved Sunset.
author: Flora B.

description: This is a good place for a couple or a group. The food & beer are good. I've had appetizers and dinner here twice and everything has been great. The staff is nice, the decor is on point, clean bathroom, decent price.....I will go back.
author: Sarah S.

description: Delicious mojito! Fresh squeezed lemonade and fried chicken was perfect.
author: Claudia M.

description:
Sunset Reservoir Brewing seems to have suffered from the relentless hype machine of food superstardom, but also the from the culmination of too many ideas all at once.

For one, the food is just too overpriced and premium for the standard pub affair crowd. Or perhaps a $16 burger in the Sunset is just so out of context that it makes no sense.

On the other hand, dishes like their verde soup and pork are so damn delicious that it completely offsets their mediocre beer selection. One begins to think why they didn't just open up a restaurant if that was their main goal.

Growing pains aside, the team here is off to a good start. Focus on improving the beer, lower their portions and prices, and then finding a better operating rhythm for waiting lists -- then perhaps you'll end up having the next hippest neighborhood family spot in the area.
author: Anthony N.

description:
Nothing had changed since the last time I went here. What a bummer!

Still confused why you have to buy sub par bar food to sit down. 

Also there was a lot less people the other night I went. I wonder why....
author: Momoe K.

description: 2nd time at this restaurant/brewery, I found their food alright, it's nothing spectacular but good meals. The beers are alright, again very much the same with lack of flavors. The reason for the 1 star reviews because on my last visit I found a thumb tack in my pizza, the restaurant and myself where lucky I did not bite the pin hard enough to stab my mouth but still very unexpected. I showed the server and got the pizza and a round of drinks comped but not the entire meal and never did they really address me about the situation. Never talked to a manager and really they just covered it by saying we will comp you drinks and a pizza. The lack of a real apology left me feeling that the management could have handled this situation better.
author: Nicholas J.

description: Hidden gem! Love the laid back vibe of this place. The food is great (highly recommend the fried green beans) and they have up to six beers on tap made in their brewery on site. Definitely worth checking out.
author: Lauren S.

description:
If I could give this no stars I would 
Ordered the sliders at least 20 mins went by we asked the server for an update as it wasn't that busy and it seemed a long time he said there was a back order on sliders. 
A. We were not informed of this when we ordered and 
B. It honestly seemed like they had forgotten to put or order in
20 more mins went by and the food finally came out!
We finished our food paid and left. Not long after my husband became violently ill! He had food poisoning! Since the sliders were the only thing he ate we are certain that was the cause!
I called today to let them know our experience so that someone else didn't get food poising but to be honest the phone call I had with them was pointless the manager wasn't there and no one could help me I explained that I didn't really need to talk to the manager but that I jut wanted to inform them of the food poising so that no one else experienced this! The girl on the phone told me she was writing it down and would pass the info onto the manager when he came in! Should you not be passing it onto the chief? Immediately so that the food can be checked????
author: Lauren F.

description:
Finally came here for the first time and celebrated a belated birthday lunch with a friend. Because there is no sign, it will be easy to miss

Food: we ordered the tequila-lime wings (1.5 lbs!) and the flatbread.  While we enjoyed our flatbread, we really loved the wings; tender white meat that's nicely seasoned and mixed well in a tequila-lime sauce.  

Drinks: wanting a beer, but can't decide?  Go for the sampler flight; 5 different beers, each in a 4-oz. glass and served in a 6-cup muffin tin.  I'm not usually a fan of beer, but I decided to go out of my comfort zone and tried the sampler; after tasting all, I enjoyed wheat beer: not too heavy, nor too bitter and had a unique, clean, bready finish.
author: Jessica S.

description:
Very hipster joint for a place in the Sunset!

Service: While waiting to be seated on a weeknight, we were able to order drinks at the bar. The waitress was kind, but not as attentive as I'd like. We were served some tiny cups for water and didn't get any refills the entire time we were there. When she came to check on us before I could as for a refill she already walked away. ):

Food: SUPER EXPENSIVE. My friends got $18 appetizers and I tried the pork shank based on other yelp recommendations. The waitress also said it was there most popular dish. Verdict? SUPER SALTY. The spetzle was drenched in the shank sauce and overly seasoned. The shank itself was gigantic but waaaayy too fatty. I left feeling really sick and heavy after eating 70% of the dish. Not worth the $24 in my opinion. 

Also, my friend said her Clams and Chorizo was way too salty. 

Overall nice bar to hang out and great atmosphere (they had the warriors game playing!) but service and food was average.
author: Maggie Y.

description:
I ordered "the burger" it was pretty damn good. This place I'd say is somewhat pricey. The atmosphere is solid. The bar is cool. The staff isn't the greatest with service but, food and alcohol make up for any negatives.
I will be coming back for sure!!! I wish they were open later!!!
author: Andrew S.

description:
if it ain't broke, don't fix it.  The fried chicken USED to be a good dish but not anymore.  Now it's a flattened piece of boneless thigh set on your plate with a weird mashed potato and gravy and coleslaw.  I'm not sure why they changed this dish but they did and we don't like it.
Otherwise, still a favorite neighborhood choice for an easy dinner with the kids. Delicious moscow mules, they use Tito's vodka and you don't even have to ask!  Brussel sprouts, beat salad, wings are still really good.    We had a nice discussion with our server about how much we love buffalo wings with the hot sauce.  So we were a bit surprised when they brought up a bowl of BBQ wings instead........she explained that it's kind of busy and that things were crazy in the kitchen.  I looked around, we were practically the only ones in the restaurant (it was a wednesday night) 
so I don't know what was causing the craziness.  Plus they had a live band playing, which is fine but it's really, really , really loud.  really loud

I'll still go back.  but hopefully they fix the fried chicken
author: Rio K.

description: I used to love this place my roommates and I used to go multiple times a week until they had a new chef. Before it was pricey $15 for an ok size fish and chips. Now it's the same price for almost no fish. Same with Taco Tuesdays. Before a decent deal now you get less for the same price. Only reason it's 2 stars and not one because the drinks are good.
author: Patrick P.

description: I've been here previously for lunch on the weekend, since it's in my neighborhood. I visited last night with my cousin. Walked in, sat at the bar, waited at least 5 mins, no acknowledgement of us sitting down--so, I went up to the hostess and checked, "if we sit at the bar, can we still order food?" "Yes! Absolutely!" "Great, may I see a menu?" Cool. Sat down again at the bar...looked through the menu along with Yelp. The two bartenders there made no motion to greet us, no hey welcome, I'll be right with you; or can I get you guys something to drink? We waited a solid amount of time to see if they would even wave hey from afar. Haha! She noticed we were there, but made no motion to say hi. Needless to say, it rubbed us the wrong way and felt the need to leave. Such a shame. The space is wonderful, but the service and food is subpar.
author: Mariel A.

description: Met my cousin here for lunch..it was a very pleasant surprise.  Great service.  They brew their own beer.   The food was great. I had the roasted chicken, it was a little dry, but the mashed potatoes and gravy were awesome.  My daughter had the mac n cheese, soooo good and my other daughter had the Ceaser Salad with grilled chicken..yummy.   Did not have dessert.  I highly recommend this place!
author: Lanya S.

description:
I first tried coming here on a Friday night, which was a big mistake. It was so crowded, and the expected wait time was 1.5 hours. I decided to skip it that day, so I went on a Tuesday night, but it was still crowded! The hostess told me it would be a 45 minute wait, but it actually turned out to be a 20 minute wait. 

I ordered the golden gate mule and pan seared trout. The mule is made with homemade ginger beer, and boy was that ginger potent! That was all I could taste, but I love ginger, so I didn't mind. It might be too strong for other folks though. And my trout was good, but for the portion, it was overpriced. The potatoes also weren't cooked all the way. Not a fan of crunchy potatoes. 

This was a neat space, but I felt like the food was ok and overpriced.
author: Rachel H.

description: This is my new favorite place in the sunset.  Taco tuesday is great, burger is great, drink is strong, russian beer is great, but the bartenders are what keep me coming by!  Dave, Jeramiah(spellcheck), everyone
author: Choladeva C.

description:
Good bear and burger 
Service was nice but very slow ----despite place being practically empty

Other food options are hit and miss and all food seems pricey for what you get
author: P K.

description: Lovely atmosphere, good music, and great people. Have come here on quite a few occasions and thoroughly enjoyed myself each time. The bartender Jeremiah greeted us with a smile and made some great recommendations-- amazing beverages and scrumptious food. Really quality experience at the bar overall. Will definitely be back! 2 thumbs up!
author: Amelia S.

description:
It's an interesting setup for a brewery but overall, I think it's quite spacious and very modern looking. But let's be real and talk about the food.

We split an order of the fried macaroni and cheese bites. Though they were a bit salty, they were complemented with our drinks. My fiancé and I split a Caesar salad which we both thought was a great balance and loved the way it was served up. As for our entrees, he got the Mussels and Chorizo and I got the Fish & Chips. For his entree, his only complaint is that he would have preferred sourdough bread but the dish itself was great. As for me, the fish was a bit inconsistent (one piece soggy and unflavourful, the others ranged in salt and were crispy). Despite the inconsistency, I'd still be back because their fries, the macaroni and cheese bites, salad, and my wine was on point.
author: Shauna S.

description: 4 stars for food and service 0 for hospitality.  I asked if i could have the wifi password, i was told no because it slowed down their pos.  I think thats a bunch of BS.
author: David R.

description:
Great scene in an unpretentious neighborhood.

Probably the best place to get a beer in the Sunset!
author: Jacob J.

description:
Very disappointing experience: especially since my husband and I live in the sunset and were at first excited to try new local "hipster" place. We also like independent breweries. 

However, the sunset reservoir brewing company fell very short our expectations. 
Liked: modern design, food we ordered (many appetizers to share) pretty decent.
Fell short: beers were mediocre and nothing to write home about. Pretty flat taste. since they are a brewery the beers were supposed to be a center piece. Not here.

Most importantly: very very disappointing service. very impersonal. The server had mean attitude whole evening. 

Everyone we spoke to acted like it's a great deal for them to help us and probably we should be happy they give us a minute of their valuable time, instead of like "welcome to our brewery, you are our guest, how can we make it great for you."

Final thing which made my dinner with friends - my birthday dinner - very uncomfortable was that they suddenly turned on music super super loud, and started loudly placing chairs on top of the tables right next to our faces - apparently they close at 10? (It was 10:20 when we left so that crazy commission accompanied by Beyoncé started at 10:10).

My friend spoke to one of the team and they admitted yes that's the way they always use to get customers out. Clearly no one knows how to say "hi, we are closing in 15 mins" first. No one EVER during the evening mentioned they are about to close or closed. 
Since the team member admitted this RUDE situation, cold good bye was a normal practice, not an incident - this is even worse! They knew it was wrong and they did it by purpose. Very disrespectful.
You know that how to say good bye to customers is an essential part of business. Whole experience is spoiled if you feel unwelcomed and treated like ok give us your Credit card and get the hell out here.

The manager was "not available" to speak to. 
The manager should supervise their stuff because we could see after they finished placing chairs around us they just sat and chatted and relaxed with beers.
The manager should train their stuff customer service skills. Clearly - this service was NOT PROFESSIONAL.
But you know what, the whole situation was just about being so rude, that every one with common sense would not do; you don't need any special training to be nice and respectful.


There are sooo many great places in the city with offer great food AND great welcoming warm service.
These guys - do not!

I thought it would be friendly neighborhood place you can visit frequently, instead it's more like mean hipsters who think they are way too cool. 

1 star for food. Zero for service. Zero for beer. Never try again. They don't respect or appreciate your business there.
author: Dimi N.

description: My wife and I have been eating here since they've opened... We've had everything on the menu... Everything on the menu are great....But...They need to change the menu...Seems very little change on menu items in all this time....Oh, no wifi... REALLY !
author: David R.

description:
Cute spot hidden away in the Outer Sunset. 

After a sand-filled afternoon at Ocean Beach, we made a stop here for dinner before heading home. The Google Lady (aka, the GPS) directed us here after we failed miserably to find it on our own. Probably doesn't help that there's no sign, but the sign wouldn't have saved me from the many wrong turns I made on the way over. 

It's super nondescript, so if you don't have your own Google Lady or a friend who has been here before, it's probably easily missed. But again, we were at the beach, with a toddler, so I needed beer and the help of the Google Lady. 

We were happy to see that we weren't the only parents there (woo hoo!) and super grateful that they had a kids menu (which comes in the form of a fun activity placemat with two brown crayons. Clever!). 

Family-friendly places with beer are an easy win for me and so much more when they have a decent bar and food menu. The kid had spaghetti, my dude had the cioppino, I had the fried chicken, and we all shared a side of green (and wax) beans with cauliflower. All was pretty tasty, especially the bean and cauliflower. Mmmmmm.  

The best part for me was that we weren't made to feel out-of-place for bringing our kid. We were seated in the upper area, which, with all the high chairs set out, looked very much like the "kid area." It made me smile. Little Dude loved seeing and remarking on all the other "babies." Being able to go out and enjoy an adult drink and meal around other like-minded families is such a relief and feels so great. You have no idea.

We're already making plans to go back. 

Probably just us though, so we can drink and eat slower.

Extra: 
We did a post-meal walk around the block which led us up the hill to a gorgeous view of the Pacific Ocean from one corner and a lovely view of the Golden Gate Bridge from the other.
author: Loli L.

description:
Nice interior and break from Asian food in the Sunset. Really cozy - definitely looks like Southern Pacific brewery inside.

We shared a pizza, brussels sprouts, roasted veggie side, and tacos along with the beer sampler. The food was not bad but a bit on the bland side. The beer sampler had really generous pours. 

Service started out friendly but became distant and unavailable later on. From previous reviews, it looks like their billing system has issues. The server brought us someone else's check. Then the total check after card swiped was the right amount. 

Definitely a solid place to hangout for a couple beers and maybe an app but don't recommend for a full dinner or meal.
author: Tina G.

description: Came to eat here on Saturday 9/2 after a day at the beach.  It was a  very hot evening. My party of 4 had to wait 35 minutes for a table. Apparently this place does not have air conditioner so people didnt want to sit on the second floor where it was hotter. After waiting for a long time,  I was so hungry. We placed our order  a few mintues after we were seated. When our food arrived my order wasnt placed so i had to wait yet another 25 mins. My party ate their meal. So when my food finally arrived everyone was done.  How fun was that, to eat alone. Wasn't  happy about that, but the waitress did apologize and told me my food was on them. Was compensated so i was satisfied with that. The burgers we order were not as we expected very small in size, nothing like their add online.  They also didnt have the desserts that are one their website menu either. My daughter was bummed out.  I don't think I will return. There are other places
author: Diana G.

description:
The food is absolutely great. The Russian Imperial Stout is great. Loved the black bean tortilla
Soup. Staff is friendly and fast. All around great place.
author: Christina F.

description:
THE BEST FRIES. Well-seasoned and the chipotle aioli is on point. 
Food is a bit pricy for what I normally go for, but you get filled up on the apps and small plates. Love the vegetarian black bean soup, baked mac and cheese, the sliders, and caesar salad. 
I've had great service every time I've come! Overall, a fun place!
author: Tess K.

description: All I can say is this place is just okay. The burger was super greasy, the fries were over done, and beer is ehh at best. The wait staff is super nice and attentive though.
author: Emily C.

description: Beer is ok, nothing special. Bartenders seem both undertrained and overwhelmed. Did not have food, so can't judge that. Big time hipster doofus vibe.
author: G W.

description: Great ambience and good cocktails & food. The staff was also friendly and attentive. The shisito peppers were amazing!  Such a blessing to have a cool place like this in the 'Set. Can't wait to go back!
author: M E.

description:
This place was super rad! I had a mojito, which was stellar, and the burger off the brunch menu. Super good service as well. Reasonable pricing. I'd definitely go back anytime. Also loved the family
Friendly vibe!
author: Leigh W.

description: Very cool place! The venue is great for large parties, staff is extremely nice, and the food is incredible. The cocktails are delicious, I tried about four off the menu and found myself even more satisfied as the drinks kept coming.  Service was a tad slow considering it was a Wednesday when I went. I will definitely return.
author: P F.

description:
Dined and drank on a recent Saturday in mid January. First time at SRBC. I live right down the street on Noriega and am delighted to have a non-Asian eatery in my hood. As a hapa, I enjoy paying respect to my Asian culture by grubbing down, but grow tired of it every once in a while.

Service was attentive and friendly. Young male server was typical SF -- laid back and funny. Although he didn't know as much details about the menu, I appreciated his efforts and willingness to ask the kitchen, and promptly answer our questions.

Ordered several items but the standouts: basket of wings was plentiful and delicious. I appreciate the generous portion of wings, especially because my group shared it. The french fries were delicious, accompanied by jalapeño ranch sauce. The sliders were OK, nothing extraordinary but decent. One of my dining companions had the fish/fry basket and it was HUGE, she couldn't even finish it. But the value was there, and she enjoyed what she could manage to eat. Most of the grub we had was flavorful.

On an aside, I'm not a beer drinker, and was glad to see SRBC has a mixed drink menu.

Prices are as expected.

I'll be back, SRBC.
author: Cameron M.

description:
In my opinion this place deserves 2.5 stars, but since Yelp does not allow that, I'm bumping up to 3 stars since the place is kid friendly and my hubby enjoyed the dinner special of the night (seared rack of lamb on a bed of lentils).

Love the physical space itself, but the food was mediocre at best. Had high expectations of the fried chicken based on previous reviews, but it was under-seasoned, unevenly coated and some parts of the coating were soggy. While the chicken was hot, the mashed potatoes were warm-cold and the coleslaw fell flat (maybe needs a touch of acidity to brighten up). 

Ordered two kids meals for my children (fish n chips and fried chicken). Both came with salad which seems strange for a kids meal - I'd suggest broccoli as a better accompaniment for kids. my daughter had the chicken, which was as lackluster as mine. My son had the fish and chips which he seemed to enjoy. The fries were unremarkable.

Hubby enjoyed the brews he tried, so I'd recommend this place for drinks and nibblies, but not for dinner. Too many better options around than to come back here again.
author: Melissa S.

description:
The Sunset District used to be depressingly in need of a great bakery, and then Devil's Teeth Baking Co. came and saved the day. The same owner has now rescued us from the overpopulation of cheap Chinese restaurants and bubble tea places in this area. Although I can't speak for the beer (we came for brunch with our kids), the food is legit!! Everything we ordered was absolutely delicious, and any component that contained bread (e.g. French toast, eggs Benedict, breakfast biscuits) were totally bolstered by the same mad baking skills inherited from Devil's Teeth. Every bite is flavorful, and I love some of their unique flavor combinations. The fried chicken sandwich is also a must-try!

We will definitely be back some time to try the dinner. In the meantime, if you're looking for a great brunch experience in the Sunset with a great laid back atmosphere, you have to try this place!
author: Rachel M.

description:
Loud, hipster brew-pub. Once one gets over that, it's pretty good if pricey (I did say "hipster", right?). Nice decor except for the large sports video screens.

The menu is a bit small, and most items seem to be a American traditional dish with a hipster twist: the spinach and beet salad has quinoa; the burger has an aioli; the mussels have chipotle. Fine, except I don't like most of their twists.

Twists and all, the food is good. The burger was very good (aioli on the side). The fish and chips were solid, but the fries are fine, but not great.

Service was excellent except that we had to keep asking for more water, served in small glasses. Perhaps they think that if they don't give much water, we will order more beer. Instead, the lack of water annoyed us, especially the designated driver (me).
author: Richard H.

description:
I don't want to spend much time thinking/writing about this place anymore than I have to. Great ambiance, location and just atmosphere. Nice people, not too crowded, a nice little gem in the sunset. Sub-par beer, mediocre overpriced food. 

Probably would not come back unless a lot of people start telling me things have changed.
author: Michael L.

description: Whiskey sours were delicious and beautifully presented. The risotto and fried chicken were flavorful. Kids' menu has great options; our kids enjoy the Mac n cheese. Great family-friendly spot.
author: Mare M.

description:
In the outer sunset, there aren't many choices in the way of hipster eateries that brew their own beer, have the unfinished wood look, and also have the wall of succulents.

SRB (which doesn't have a noticeable sign or awning), is a great establishment in an otherwise sleepy neighborhood. They brew a small selection of beers which are tasty and the food is well done. Can't really ask for more.
author: Ryuta O.

description:
If they have the fried chicken appetizer, get it (comes with some tasty red sauce).

Try the Sour Wheat beer (it is not like any other sour I've had... it is real good).

Sure, the booths might be "hard," but the ambiance is perfect, the service is genuine, and you can trust that pretty much whatever you order will taste really good (the menu changes seasonally).  As of now, there's not usually a wait, which makes me like it even morrrrre.  

Just go here.
author: Kelly L.

description: Yum! After searching for the elusive parking spot, we entered the brewery and met the hostess as we walked in. Although we didn't have reservations we were seated within 5 minutes. The food was hot and fast. My burger was spot on and filling. The Mr's fish and chips were l little too much breading and not enough fish. A few pieces were a little battery. (Not quite finished frying). The drink I had, a bramble something was tasty but kind of weak. Overall we were satisfied. My husband had the sour wheat beer. It was very good. Sort of like Kombucha.
author: Mary W.

description:
This is a wonderful addition for a kid friendly place to spend  time on a Friday night for a family dinner out.
First:  the guy with the long braid (works Friday nights).. this guy is a pretentious, unable to co-exist and a snot... Total jerk and negative.. I will be Mommy blogging fore warning all...
With that aside..
This is a wonderful place and exceptional service from Ryan and Cordelia.. 
Good food, good variety, good brew. Very laid back environment and a wonderful addition to the sunset district....
author: River B.

description:
Excellent food, affordable and great beers.

I came here with friends last night and we got a variety of food and beers. I got the beer sampler ($12 for 6 beers, and they were probably 4 ounces each) and the fettucine meat sauce pasta. I loved my meal because it was tasty and a hefty portion.

My friends all liked their food a lot too. We got shishito peppers and roasted nuts for appetizers, and that's some good drinking food!

I hope they increase their beer selections in the future, but I'll definitely come back.
author: Josh O.

description: This place gets packed even during the weekday! Lots of good company. The staff are very friendly, inviting, and knowledgeable. The bartenders know what they are serving and can explain the difference between beers. Even when I was so lucky to grab a bar table, the wait staff still asked me if I wanted a table on the restaurant side. I give it a thumbs up service
author: Ken O.

description:
Decent food, good service, cool spot with an extra star cause it brought some flavor to Noriega. 
When I get fried chicken it's a splurge. The two orders at our table were only partially breaded and tasted baked. The water from the veggies sogged up what may have been few parts of crispy-ish skin. 
Heard the burger was good, but the fries overdone. 

Being opened by Devil's Teeth Baking Company, I again decided to splurge and get the pie. Sadly, the pie crust was soggy, the bottom almost not done. 

Would probably give it another try but that's about it. We've got too many spots in SF to check out!
author: Emily W.

description:
The Sunset really needed a place like the SRBC.  In this district inundated with Asian mom and pop eateries and shops, there is a huge void for a hip brewery hangout spot.  The new neighborhood watering hole caught a lot of attention since it's opening, and pretty much everyone and their mama flocked to check out the new place.  Having replaced the space of an old grocery store, SRBC remodeled the building into a nice looking open concept bar and restaurant spanning two floors.  They do have the beer brewing on site and you can see the large beer vats.  But - as other yelpers mentioned, there are definitely kinks that need to be worked out.   

Our group of friends met up with a reservation via Yelp Seatme for a late dinner/snack/dessert/brew.  We wanted to make a ressie since other friends of ours mentioned having to wait 1.5 hours for a table on a separate occasion.  The bar area is nice and there's plenty of seating on both floors.  It's nice that they have a huge projector to show the SF Giants and Warriors games on the huge wall above the bar.  I can see this place getting really packed come playoff time.  We didn't have any problem getting seated upstairs promptly.  The upstairs area seems to be used for larger groups and probably could be rented out for parties since there is another small bar up there too.  It wasn't open that evening though.  

We were all impressed by the ambiance and reveled in the novelty of SRBC for the first few minutes.  After that, a rather disappointing experience ensued.  Our server was a delightful young lady but she was a complete amateur waitress.  She would disappear for long periods of time and no one checked on us for 20-30-60 minutes intervals.  We were there for a good amount of time but it seemed really difficult to get any type of service.   The waitress didn't actually bring us any waters until a whole hour after we ordered beers.  When we did order some food, she didn't bring us any small plates until after the food arrived.  A few people at our table ordered the beer flight and someone came to drop them off without any explanation of what was what.  It wasn't until much later that our waitress finally came to check on us and we had to ask her to point out the different types of beers.  The wait staff was very disorganized at SRBC and even servers who brought out the food didn't know which tables to bring them to.  

What was a huge let down was actually the beer itself.  I ordered their Irish stout since that's my favorite type of beer.  I did get try each of the beers from other half's flight and didn't think any of them were great.  I'm not a huge beer drinker but I think I know a good brew.  The overall consensus at our table was that all the beer were just mediocre.  I thought a few tasted watered down and flat.  Flights are $10 and pints are $6.  Reasonably priced but there sure are less expensive breweries around the city.     

A few of our friends ordered the wings and fries to nosh on.  I didn't try any of the food but I did order the bread pudding with strawberry ice cream ($8).  It was just OK.  It tasted like a home cook could have made it....not a culinary/pastry chef.  Another friend ordered the pork chop and he said it was good.  I thought the items on the menu were a but pricey for what they were.  Overall, SRBC is a great space with lots of potential but I only have two words for now - Needs Improvement!
author: Liv A.

description: I went with my two daughters and my wife to celebrate my daughter completing her first year of veterinary school.  We had the blistered shishito peppers and the homemade soft pretzel as appetizers. Both were delicious. We shared the large version of two salads, the Sunset Ceasar and the rosemary pear & arugula salad.  I especially like the rosemary pear and arugula salad.I had the three sliders from the small plate menu, my oldest daughter the mac and cheese, my wife the fried chicken and my youngest daughter the fettuccini pasta bolognese.  All were excellent and the portions generous. My wife and daughters had some of the craft beers made in house. The wait staff was attentive without being cloying.
author: Michael N.

description: Enjoyed a super chicken dish here and a tasty IPA. Okay, two IPAs.  Good setting to hang in. Got the sense that it ranges from place to be on a game night but also place to go with the family. Cool living wall deal upstairs, too. I'm in! Glad it's a part of the sunset.
author: Tigger M.

description:
A little bit pricy for quality of food.  Food is flavorful but halibut and flat iron steak slightly overcooked (very little pink for medium).  Beer could be a few degrees cooler as well.  In all fairness, we went on a warm day so downstairs was OK.  Upstairs noticeably warmer.

Despite issues mentioned, it seems to be a hip and fun place to be if you can find parking and willing to pay up.  Look elsewhere if you are looking for value.
author: Yip Y.

description: I am so glad there is a beautiful brewery and bar out in this neck of the woods. I came for lunch. I enjoyed the charred shishito peppers, fried chicken and reservoir salad. I had a golden gate mule for beverage. I will have to come back to try the beer.
author: Infodiva B.

description:
Three Stars, lemme explain.

Good food, good drinks, but service needs to change -- not impressed.

One of my girl friends took me here for my birthday. Supposedly, they just opened a couple weeks ago and of course, the place was packed (but it'll probably die down IMO). The decor is cute, typical brewery with TVs and nic nacs. Also, there's an upstairs section which creates an intimate atmosphere -- very similar to 21st Amendment. 

Anyways, the beer flights we ordered were mighty tasty and the food portions were pretty big, BUT our particular server needed a little help in the customer service department. He was weirdly questionable about our ID when we made a joke about it.  Yes, we do look young but come'on we had our IDs to prove we were wayyyy beyond 21. That was a mood killer for the rest of the night, he didn't apologize to us at all nor did he mention a "Happy Birthday" I mean, a simple HBD would be nice. Despite the ID mishap, he was mildly attentive in serving us, just thought maybe he could be more personable because we came here for a special occasion but we left feeling like we were robbed outta our night. BTW - our busser was a lot more friendlier than our server, just saying. 

A quick disclaimer -- Regarding IDs, this isn't a Vegas bar --  this is a little brewery in the sunset that may or may not stay open for longer than a year. Sorry not sorry.

Not sure if we'll be back, there's plenty more brewery you should check other than this place.
author: Julia K.

description: Our family threw us an engagement party at SRBC last weekend and it was just amazing.  The staff was so helpful and attentive, awesome food, great beers, and we just couldn't have asked for a better day.  We are locals and are so excited this place is in our neighborhood and can't wait to come back again and again!
author: Melissa F.

description:
I went with 5 other people and we all ordered different food and beer.
Very packed, food are below average and pricy. Beers are good.
Nothing really good to make me come back again.
author: BeFree Y.

description:
Everything here appears out of place. Food, Service, the Beer. Cool idea though...

Service is nonexistent, the staff shows no emotions or lack of basic customer service skills. Simple questions leads to rude or uninviting blank stares by the waitress/hostess. Either they lack communication skills or they're not happy to work.

Food - Burgers were ordered by me and my group of friends. Each burger were a different size and variation. Some buns were smaller/bigger then others, including the patty itself, was in various sizes. Quality on the burgers were hit or miss, which was disappointing

The tables are only available if you order food, so if you only have a beer or plan to only drink, expect to be rejected by the staff(even if majority of the tables are empty).

Beer - My friends & I did not see anything special or unique about it. The brewery idea is exciting. Note they also can run out of their own beers, and their special was Hefeweizen....I still don't understand how that considered special. We tried the flight of beers(I believe it was 5 different house made beers). Good amount of beer in each, if it wasn't for the excessive amount of foam on top on a few. When I mean excessive, it was nearly all foam, no liquid.

I tried this place twice to give it a second chance since I was with a different group of friends. The only thing we took out of it was the TV since it had sports on. Other then that, it was a disappointing trip. It appears if the place was trying to do too much, but in fact they can't master the basics.
author: Raymond J.

description:
Not family friendly. It's my birthday and we decided to try this new restaurant in the sunset with the whole family. Apparently they only serve food starting at 5. Isn't it supposed  to be family friendly? Families tend to like to eat early. Kids go to sleep early. 
You mean I have to go around 8-9 with my daughter in order to be served ?  Might as well get rid of the restaurant   and just leave the bar if you are worried about the extra cash you have to pay your kitchen staff for working extra hours. Alcohol will definitely make you more money.  
Never again. Bad business. Go to Social on 9th and Irving instead -they serve food in the afternoon and are family friendly.


Update.
The owner contacted me and was very kind.   we will come back again and try out their dishes soon.
author: Liza B.

description:
Three stars for the service, one star for the beer. 

I went there with a group of friends and we had a good time. 

The food was good but way too expensive. You are paying for the service and the atmosphere. Beers were around $6 and the burger & fries I ordered were around $16. The beer was hoppy and light. Burger & fries were delicious but overpriced.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
Waiting in line to get in @ 5:25pm. Supposed to be opened at 5:00pm. Had a small window to visit this place. Not going to be able to now. Restaurant staff clearly inside, but no notice to the people waits outside in the cold. SMH.

Will alter review next time I come...
author: Jiggy L.

description:
Came here Sunday night to check this brewery out because it's very close to my house, initial impression of the ambiance was great warm and inviting expect your normal brewery atmosphere. Sat at the bar and ordered a flight of their house beers.
At first our bartender was nice and friendly, however after our first beer we had some questions about the drinks and wanted to know more about the differences between the beers we had, at this point the bartender was very uneducated  about his product and slightly blew us off saying that he didn't have time and to "give him a min"
For the rest of our visit it was difficult to order more drinks which was surprising because it was a Monday night and it wasn't very busy.
Bottom line, I won't be coming here for my weekend spot, overall everything was acceptable take away the service from behind the bar.
Probably won't be returning here.
author: Kaylan K.

description:
I'll start by saying that I really do want to like this place.. It's close to my house, gorgeous on the inside, and the menu looked interesting on paper. Me and a girlfriend went last night to check it out thinking that some of the opening kinks would have been worked out by now.  

Now I understand that this is a brewery, but when you have a full bar and a specialty cocktail list, you should be able to make a decent drink. The first bartender we had was really sweet but made a pretty terrible margarita. He started by giving us brunch menus and we wanted the spicy margaritas, but when we ordered them he explained that he gave us the wrong menu and we settled on normal ones.... Overly sweet, not at all balanced, and we even upgraded the tequila, but I could not taste it at all. 

Then we ordered some food - the burger and the meat and cheese plate to share. The burger was pretty delicious - juicy, flavorful, nice soft bun. The fries were really good too, but we had to ask for ketchup twice. The meat/cheese plate was a sad sad portrayal. Two cheeses, both superrrrr hard (bleu cheese should not be that hard) and two cured meats that were never explained to us. The "accruements" were cornichons and two hard pieces of toast - no sweet jam, figs, nuts... nothing. 

We picked at the food and chatted for a while with empty glasses, and waiting probably 25 mins before finally flagging someone down to order more drinks. We decided on Moscow Mules, and the bartender asked whether we wanted traditional ones or their specialty ones. We asked what the specialty one was which caught him very off guard and he had to go get a menu to see what actually was special about it. He ended up giving us vodka sodas with lime in copper mugs. 

Overall these are kind of nit picky things to complain about, I understand that. But when you have 3 bartenders and a bar back behind the bar and are still receiving little to no service, that doesn't sit right with me (esp when paying $100.00 between 2 people). I do hope that they get it together because this has great potential for a neighborhood go-to spot. Maybe I'll check it out again in the next couple months, but until then, I say pass.
author: Anna K.

description:
the SF Giants were on their two flat screen TV, so automatically plus already. came on a weekend around 2 pm, there're open tables but probably those tables are not covered. only 15mins wait. we got seated near the skylight. On a hot day, it gets hot when the sun hits the table. so make sure to move your beer away from the sunlight. cold beer can turn room temperature quick. 

their iced tea is $3 and free refill. I got second refill and waitress asked if I wanted a third. that kind of gesture is rare so another plus for that. the flight of beer is now $12. comes with a sheet listing the beers. good taster to see which beer you like. 

the fettuccine bolognese with chorizo, cherry tomatoes, and Parmesan was pretty good. It was a big dish for me, so I had left overs. the pasta was just right but I think I will ask for al dente next time. I forgot to. $18

Their fried chicken is boneless thighs, served with mashed potato, pork gravy, and coleslaw. wished it was bone-in. I would have prefer it that way. $18

The shishito peppers was a little bland even with the jalapeño ranch and salt. $8 for this dish. 

overall good service. no offer of free water refill but I am sure when asked, they would. was too full to check out the dessert menu. Next time!
author: Jules L.

description:
I have had the chance to check out Sunset Reservoir Brewing Co. several times since it opened back in February and it has gotten better every time.  I remember walking in the first weekend they opened and being pretty underwhelmed. But now that the dust has settled it's one of my favorite places in the Sunset.  

        Beer & Drinks: (4/5) Studies have shown that in SF a new brewery opens roughly every 80 seconds * (*no actual data was collected in the making of this study) so the beer has to be special to make a splash.  Make sure to get the flight if you've not tried any of their homebrews; I also enjoy that the glasses come in a clever muffin tin configuration.  The stars of the show in my eyes were the Double IPA and Dry Irish Stout. The sour wheat has a strong sourdough bread aftertaste, this may seem weird but I enjoyed it.  Also Sunset Reservoir has a good mix of cocktails on their menu if beer is not your thing. The Elderhound and Buffalo Mule were both fantastic and well worth the purchase.

    Food: (4/5)  I've had a smattering of the sides and one or two of the dinners.  By far I think you get the best deal by getting the Sunset Burger with Fries.  In classic California fashion it has avocado on top as well as bacon, both of which have been proven to help you age slower.  The fired chicken thighs are also not to be missed or the bowl of wings. NOTE - the bowl of wings contains roughly 100,000 wings. Two friends and myself had trouble finishing the bowl it was so full.

Setting: (4/5) Ive been told that the previous tenant of Sunset Reservoir's current location was some type of market and the space is big enough that i believe it.  The ceilings are high and vaulted with reclaimed wood and metal making up the majority of the decor.  They also have two TV's typically playing whatever Bay Area team is currently kicking butt near the bar and a second floor for larger parties.

All in all a solid place to go for a beer and grab a bite.
author: Ryan F.

description:
Been here 4 times, my friends like the relaxing environment during lunch

The menu has changed since I first stepped in. 
The fettuccine Bolognese is good
The buffalo wings were kinda dry and needed extra buffalo sauce
My friends like the beet salad
The fried chicken thighs are kinda dry and need some BBQ sauce

The servers and bartenders are really polite.
author: DOM d.

description:
**Given that SRBC recently opened, I'll try them again in a few weeks to see if they've worked out their kinks.**

In the meantime, my initial experience with SRBC leaves me wanting more from their customer service.

We came after dinner hours on a weekend to try to the beer.  The beer was pretty decent, but nothing I would wait in a Soviet bread line for.

Suggestions: 

-Staff: If you make eye contact with guests coming through the door, greet said guests.

-Bartender: When dealing with inquisitive customers asking about the beer tasting flight, don't hand them a flight tasting half-sheet, tell them the information is there, and then walk off to help someone else. 
Tell them the information is on the halfsheet, but also include something along the lines of, "We're real busy right now, but feel free come back to me with any questions you may have. The staff can also help you as available."

-Include a chalkboard or display of beer options. It'd also be good to have something letting guests know if bottled beer is avaliable for purchase, or if you can get a growler filled.

-Protect your menus in sleeves, or laminate them--it's kind of gross to handle a sheet with wet spots.

-Have staff make one group announcement for last call/finish drinks. Having a guy selectively go around telling some people they need to finish their drinks, while others go about sipping freely gives the wrong impression.

Overall, I'm really hoping SRBC works the kinks out in time. The venue is lovely, and I'd love to see success with their family-friendly concept. Hopefully service improves and stays away from being labeled a douchey pretentious hipster destination. We already have SoPac Brewery in the Mission for that nonsense.
author: Sam W.

description:
Went here on the second night they were open, and I can see why people in the area are stoked to have this new restaurant/brewery! It has a beautiful, large, hip ambience. However, they have a lot of growing pains to iron out! I'd be interested in coming back in a month or two to see if they've ironed out some of the kinks. 

The house-brewed beer selection is really great. Some breweries totally miss making any sort of impression but it's totally worth it and a reasonable price. ($10 for a flight of 5).

The pickled vegetables under 'snacks' aren't pickled. At all. It's a combo of peppers, cauliflower, and jalapeno slices that have maybe been marinated in oil... ?

Of the other dishes our group ordered, the mussels were the best on the menu, and still that's kind of a stretch. The addition of chorizo was OK, but kind of strange. Less is more! 

The burger has no veggie option, which is a bummer! Our friends ordered a burger without the patty, and I'll just say it was not good. Gotta get on that veggie burger game. 

All in all, I think the space is great and the beer selection is awesome. I won't be ordering food here for awhile, and hope they simplify it/put out a stronger menu. Still a great spot to hang, and you should still check it out if you're on the fence.

Cheers!
author: Julianne M.

description:
Thank god this brewery opened up! I read several of the reviews on Yelp and to be honest I'm really surprised about many of the complaints, this place is a blessing to the Sunset, the Sunset is boring and only full of Asian restaurants to offer. The price is too expensive??? Reallyy? What world do you come from, you live in San Francisco. Go to McDonalds or BJ's and get your burger if you want something cheaper, every brewery I have been to of this class has relatively the same prices.

This place is working out the kinks, which is understandable for it being so brand new.  The owner is the same person that runs Devil's Teeth bakery, which is another top notch place in the sunset for pastries, your morning coffee, and one of the best egg sandwiches I've every had.  So she definitely knows what she's doing in terms of food.

I've had breakfast, appetizers, and a burger and beer, so my review will be based on those items.

Breakfast:
I had the chilaquiles, the clams, a pambaso and a sopa con puerco.  Chilaquiles were delicious, but they were my first to try so I can't compare to anything else in life, but they were solid.  The clams were delicious and had tons of flavor.  The pambaso was probably my favorite, it had chicken and salsa verde, the bread it came with was extremely savory and made that dish for me, as I am a bread guy (even though I wouldn't describe the dish as extremely bready).  The frijoles con puerco was very good, the pork was a little tough, but still very flavorful

Appetizers:
Had the mussells with chorizo...super good! Great flavor, and the chorizo was money!!!!!
Also had the rabbit rillettes with frisee, bacon, redcabbage jam... My wife and I split this, I was suprirsed at how good the portions were, we were able to spread the red cabbage jam on crostinis and top it with the rabbit and bacon, my favorite appetizer, red cabbage jam was delicious and I had just come somewhere from having organic bacon, and was surprised at how flavorful this bacon was, really good dish.

Burger:
The sunset burger was solid, and came with a healthy portion of fries.  Since the owner is such a creative baker, I'm waiting for her to come out with some kind of special ketchup for the fries (wink wink), but I will wait for that, either way solid burger and fries.

Beer:
Had the flight of beers just to see what I would like.  It really depend what you like as far as beer, I'm more of an IPA guy, and surprisingly their IPA wasn't my favorite, not to say it was bad, I interestingly liked the Blond Ale over the IPA, typically Blondes are too light for me, but this was to me a little more medium bodied and delicious.  Also surprising for me was the Dry Irish Stout, I hate Guiness, as I think it's so flat and one note, but this beer I actually liked even though I'd compare it to a Guiness, the only difference was it had this delicious coffee liquor kind of taste, which was quite enjoyable.  

Atmosphere/KIds/Family:
The overall atmosphere is nice and wide and spacious, all the staff are super accommodating even though many are still learning the menu and getting acquainted with the new place.  I brought my 1 year old here as well, and it was very easy on the family, didn't have that bar rowdy kind of environment, a family could easily bring their kids (son loved the chorizo and pamboso as well :)).
author: Gina A.

description:
Imagine if President Obama showed up at your local gym and asked to be the three point specialist for your next pickup basketball game - having a brewery pop up in the Sunset district is an equally surprising and welcome addition. Sunset Reservoir Brewing Company has both obvious room for improvement and strong, staying potential in the neighborhood.
 
Sunset Reservoir's in-house brews are the highlight of its menu. The Blond Ale is like the crisp breath of fresh air that is desperately needed after emerging from a crowded movie theater - it uplifts and revitalizes the drinker from not only the doldrums of a workday, but also the drowsiness threatened by the food on hand. Meanwhile, the Irish Stout is like swimming in an unlit swimming pool in the dead of night and suddenly coming upon a treasure chest - the darkly rich and smooth stout gives way to a stunning, coffee aftertaste.
 
The Sunset Burger presents a glaring plot hole in an otherwise wonderfully produced film. The patty is well-seasoned, bacon crisply fried, and dressing thoroughly enriching, but unfortunately, the state of the bun cannot be ignored. Whether due to chef's purpose or oversight attributed to unrehearsed procedures, the brioche bun that is actually still flavorful is dreadfully dry. Despite attempting willful ignorance to avoid seeming petty for sending the burger back to the kitchen over such a detail, the crumbly and moisture-robbing bread was resoundingly prominent in each bite. The medium-cut fries are a satisfying, crispy accompaniment.
 
The Pasta Bolognese is fuller than a preschooler's backpack - teeming with sausage, cheese, and flavor. Its sauce is the perfect pasta manager, striking an ideal balance in having its fingerprints on all the moving parts, while not becoming domineering in any aspect. The papardelle pliably envelops nearby sausage and cheese, automatically generating a composite bite in each forkful.
 
The service is attentive and polite, never straying far from empty water bottles or tables yet to order, while the high ceilings and woody décor create the sense of dining in a luxurious cabin. Sunset Reservoir is off to a running start, but its pricier offerings demand some improvement.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Hooray! This will be our go-to brewery in our Corner of the City (the Sunset). I'm beside myself with happiness at having a nearby spot like this

Just enjoyed the extra pale ale and the double IPA. Both solid. The extra pale was light, minimal hops, refreshing. The double IPA was cloudy, delicious, well balanced, and tasted a little like Racer 5. Not sure why other people are saying they couldn't taste the hops. My husband and I home brew IPAs and drink all the usual suspects and it has just the amount of hops you would expect. 

We also had the chilaquiles. Yummy, with lots of egg and tomato. Not as good as Nopalito. But still good.

The ambiance was industrial, spare, felt like a brewery.

Excellent service. Very friendly. We were not rushed at all and enjoyed a leisurely afternoon at our own pace. Loved the whole experience.
author: Sara H.

description: Very excited for this new spot in the Sunset. Tried their beer sampling flight and was very impressed!  The wheat beer is made with sourdough yeast and is slightly tart in flavor. Very unique and pleasant!  The beer flight is the way to go - there is a nice selection and it's tough to choose a favorite. This brew pub is different than a lot of other places I have been. A very rustic ambience with an elegant touch, the food menu has something for everyone. The owner also owns a bakery, so be sure to order dessert!
author: Wil H.

description:
I give Sunset Reservoir Brewing Co. a really solid 4 stars.  
First I would like to comment on the service level - which was outstanding.  
I'm sorry I don't recall her name, but on 6/2 the younger waitress was incredible.
We had a variety of food, most were really good.  The wings are a must.  The Burger is solid - it is a moist gooey burger.  I had the beer sampler, as I wanted to try them all and figure which would be my favorites for next time.  I think they could stand to add a standard blonde, hefe, or pilsner, as all the options are in depth beers.  The beers are good, and distinctive.  

A great option for the Sunset.
author: Mike A.

description: Great french toast! Crunchy and soft at the same time. Hip decor, nice ambience.
author: Rob H.

description: This is a neat spot for drinks. It's location is a bit odd but I think it brings a lot of personality to the neighborhood. We ordered the wings and fries- very typical of me. I like that they offered so many wings for a good price. But they were just okay, pretty much threw sauce on the wings and tossed it around. The french fries were similar to In-n-Out just a little thicker. Overall, food and experience was okay.
author: Dara S.

description: Food is pretty good. Service friendly but a bit slow upstairs. Noise level was high but not terrible. The bar is open, ceilings are cry high (especially for the Sunset). Was a very nice evening.
author: Alison L.

description:
New place in the neighborhood so we checked it out on Friday at happy hour. It was pretty good however there was about a 15 minute wait for a table.  The food was okay but the beer excellent. 

I only gave it four stars because there's no signage on the front of the building and you don't know what it is unless you walk up close and look in the window, at that point you see a printed out paper menu which has the name of the bar/restaurant on it also there's a little parking on Noriega.
author: Kelly I.

description:
Great energy and vibe to this place.  The design strikes me as being very similar to Site Glass in SOMA.  Two levels, lots of reclaimed looking wood, metal railings, rustic aesthetic.

The beers I tried were the pale ale and the stout.  They were both very good, but the bar is set very high for locally produced craft beers at this moment, and I think they have a ways to go to keep up with the likes of Cellarmaker and Speakeasy.  

I ordered the mussels and oysters, and they were very good as well.  The Cobb salad is fairly plain, while the Sunset burger is clearly a nod to In-N-Out's double double.  

This is a great addition to the Noriega commercial district, and will hopefully provide an overflow crowd that the other local businesses will benefit from.  We need more nightlife in the Outer Sunset, and this place is a good start.
author: Gopal R.

description:
1/2017

I've been here a few times since my first posting when they first opened.  The last time i ate there, I wasn't sure what happened to the calamari appetizer that I've ordered every time.  That night, there was only a few calamari pieces on top of a salad of cucumber and turnip slices and coleslaw.  And strangely enough, squid ink.  We ordered calamari, not squid ink cole slaw salad.  Very disappointing.  Their fried chicken;  don't bother.  It was the first time i ordered it and it was flattened pieces of chicken that was breaded and fried.  The chicken pieces were very thin, thinner that one side of the fried batter that coated it.  The mashed potatoes were ok, but they need to skip that soupy gravy that sits atop it.  The coleslaw was good.   The pizza:  my friend ordered it and it came out piping hot.  Except that the crust was still doughy and raw underneath.  It went back into the kitchen to go in the oven a little longer.  And came out with the bottom a bit burnt.  The guy came out from the kitchen and offered to make a new one and that one came out the way it was supposed to.  

With the quality of the prepared dishes, I do feel it's overpriced.  

The bar has always been good with attentive bartenders.  The bar would be a 4.

------------------------------
Yup, still working out the kinks.

Arriving a 8pm on a saturday guarantees SRBC to be jam packed.  We waited about 20 minutes before we were able to get a bartender's attention and order our drinks.  No complaints about that, the bar was lined 2 deep.  If you go around 5:30 and earlier or after 9:30pm, it is far less crowded.  There were also no kids there at 8pm onwards this saturday night.

We had a large group at the bar ordering drinks and food.  The fries took about 60 minutes to arrive because we were told the kitchen accidentally cancelled the order, but things like salads and items that did not need to be cooked arrived quickly.  I left by 10pm before our group of 6-8 was supposed to be seated since, lightweight.  But at 8pm, they ran out of one of the beers, and by 9:30, they only had 3 beers left (if people were interested in the flights with include 5 beers.)  For groups going there, be sure to have a reservation as larger groups will guarantee you to wait until late for a larger table to open up.  It gets noisy there, but not a bomb rating loud.  

The bartender got my subsequent order of the reservoir salad and the golden gate standard mule and ended up over charging me. Unless the prices on the menu is incorrect.  I prob should have mentioned it to her, but i was buzzed on my first drink and tipped on top of that.  I also wanted the chocolate stout cake, but they ran out of that (too).

THERE ARE BATHROOMS ON BOTH FLOORS OF THE SRBC.  There's a handicapped bathroom on the ground floor where both sexes can use. I am told the upper floor has mens and women's restrooms, separate.  The brewery does need to put extra TP around or have staff periodically check the bathrooms because by 9:45pm, there was no TP in the ground floor bathroom and everyone was using the hand paper towels. And you know, there will be at least a few people throwing the nonflushable paper towels down the toilet in their drunken state.  Don't want to clog it and have it flood. (That would clear the place.)

They now open at 10am on sundays and noon the rest of the week, when previously the open time was after 5pm.  So they're making steps in the right direction.
author: Animal K.

description:
We're teetotalers who live in the neighborhood, and had to come check out the new trendy place.  

Food = 2.5 stars.  Sunset Burger didn't have vegetarian option so they basically removed the meat and gave me the so-so buns with melted cheese, and too-few vegetables.   The pozole was the only gluten-free option and it was too salty... more like a dip, not good for soup.

Service = 4.5 stars.  Very nice but very busy.  Our waitress Abby rocks.
author: George K.

description:
Sunset Reservoir Brewing Company is another highly touted new SF restaurant (or restaurant/brewery hybrid, in this case) that is amazing on paper but middle of the road in practice.

We went on a Friday night, and there was a one hour wait at about 6pm. To their credit, they were right on the money with the time estimate. We had a few of their beers at the bar while we waited. I'm no beer connoisseur, but I'd rate the beers we tried as follows: stout: B+, extra pale ale: B-, sour wheat: B.  

The ambiance of SRBC was maybe the best part. The layout is beautiful and interesting. The crowd was diverse: young and old, singles and families, etc. All of this amounted to a very welcoming experience.

We finally sat and ordered shishito peppers to start. They were fine; they're kind of a hard thing to mess up. For mains, we ordered the burger with fries and the pork shank with Sriracha spätzle. The burger was ordinary, paling in comparison to the best SF burgers. The fries that came with the burger were undercooked (i.e., tasted like raw potato). The pork shank was pretty good -- not overly flavorful but cooked well and tasty enough. I really liked the inventive take on their spätzle, which I may try and recreate in the home kitchen.

If I lived within walking distance of SRBC, I would stop by for a brew on the semi-regular. However, given that SRBC is a hike and a half, it's likely a one-and-done for me.
author: Matt T.

description:
Uh... I think I'm going to wait a little while until they get over their growing pains before I try this place again.

Seating - eh. It was a packed house and we couldn't be seated in the "dining" area because we went between lunch and dinner, even though we had no intention of ordering food. We trudged over to the bar and waited for the barflies to leave. (Side note: Southern Pacific is one of my favorite places, with a similar layout, and it has open seating regardless if you order food or not.)

Service - Our bartender was sweet but it really wasn't working. Since we were at the bar we just watched her, and other bartenders, run around like headless chickens not knowing where anything was, or what to do with themselves. It seemed like it took forever to get our beers (3 flights), she never even set up a tab (we could have walked out without paying if we weren't honest people!) and the vibe was a little too hectic for me.

THERE IS ONLY -ONE- UNISEX BATHROOM DOWNSTAIRS.
WHAT.
THE.
HECK.

If they plan on having women as patrons in this establishment, they really need to work on that! I just needed to grab some tissue from the restroom since IPAs make me sneeze immediately, and I swear I waited at least 15 minutes. Even the men waiting in line looked pained, you know how long the average woman takes in the restroom, and there was constantly a line.

Beer - I liked a few of them; Dry Irish Stout, Rye Amber, and a sour they had because the Double IPA was sold out.

I will be back... eventually.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
We were waiting for things to settle down a bit before giving this place a try and on Saturday night when the Pizza Place was, once again, a sea of wait, we decided to give it a go and were more then pleasantly surprised.

It's kind of a weird location as it doesn't have the vibe of the beach, which you get with the places located past sunset ave.  In that way it is awkward, but that's the hoods fault for being dowdy, not the restaurant.  It's huge and a lovely space, slickster with sports being projected on a big wall.  We were seated right away around 830pm and there were enough people in the place to give it atmosphere.

After reading multiple comments on small portions, we ordered a few things, thinking portions would be on par with most SF restaurants.  We were wrong.  GENEROUS portions.  In fact, only chain restaurants might give you more food.  It was a shocker. Totally negates the price, which may be a little much for that area but not for SF as a whole.  Service was efficient, friendly and looked more local then super hipster.  Our waitress was kinda out of it (though nice) but the runners for both the food and drink were totally on it. Food came fast and it was great.  We had enough left over for another full two person meal.

My one gripe is that there is only one bathroom to serve both men and women and the place seats a lot of people.  They should of split it into two when they were doing what looks like an intense build-out for that place.  So, plan accordingly and be prepared to wait.
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
